The summary of my opinion would be bland and uninspired. There isn't much for a minecraft fans, and there is nothing there really if you're not a fan. The movie isn't good, but it isn't awful either, so it doesn't get ironically funny. It's bland, with a few funny moments. It seems like the director didn't really want to commit to the minecraft lore, so the minecraft world is more of a general context, but most things from the main storyline are actually not really minecraft related. The situations the heroes are in aren't really things that exist in minecraft and the way the heroes get out of the situation isn't either. There are many subplots that are really not executed well, they don't actually advance the story at all and they just resolve at a point in the 3rd act, because that's what is supposed to happen, but there is no actual build up towards that resolution. This, all in a movie that isn't that long and that could've used the time spent on the main storyline. The movie starts with a fair amount of exposition, that doesn't really serve the story at all. The full back story of Steve is entirely irrelevant in the movie. The bits that are relevant, are repeated later during the movie. So, yeah. I wouldn't recommend this. There is nothing much for a minecraft fan there. Mostly they mention things that are in minecraft (like red stone, elytra, etc.), but they don't really do anythign with it, and the world is a minecraft-like world, but that's it. It is a bit sad. These type of movies are never extraordinary, but I would say that it isn't that hard to make a good entertaining movie for the fans. The Super Mario movie (2023) is a good example. The story is average, but they commit to the Mario world, so it is fun for a Mario fan to watch. In this case, they managed to make a movie that I would say is worst for a minecraft fan (and that is saying a lot because I really think there is nothing there for a non-minecraft fan), because you are much more aware of what isn't there that could be and would make the story better. If you haven't seen it, don't bother. It's not worth it.

It's one of the most popular games currently available and maintains a large community among its most dedicated fans. That's why its leap to the big screen will be a huge commercial success and also a fun pastime to watch. The result is a decent movie, not a masterpiece, but quite entertaining and giving fans all the heart they needed. Directed by Jared Hess, it's a surprisingly well-made adaptation that, within the world it depicts, manages to be an adaptation that confronts us with a solid comedy, built with its own references, with that '80s touch and the absurd charm of those comedies from the early 2000s that, between the implausible and the human, gave you a refreshing moment in front of the screen. However, that's not enough to say that this adaptation is a completely well-rounded film, but it does have the advantage of being quite fun to watch and that keeps you connected to the screen at all times, spending a pleasant time with this group of characters. A big plus is the cast that has a good time on screen, especially Jason Momoa, who brings out his playful side, and Momoa's comic timing is particularly impeccable. Jack Black, meanwhile, is a great host who's impossible to hate and invites you to have a good time in this adventure called Minecraft. Parents will have more fun than expected with this film, while kids and Minecraft fans will be delighted to see their favorite game make its way to the big screen. That's the grand summary that defines the film. A great CGI work and a script that, despite being quite simple, presents us with a great lesson at the end. The director's indie side is a huge plus, giving the film its charm within the mainstream adaptation of this popular game. A fun movie that delivers on its own merits. It's not a great film, but it is a decent adaptation that ultimately delivers a simple, decent time-pass for those who aren't big fans of the video game, while for those who are, it's a moment they'll enjoy from beginning to end.

A Minecraft Movie Review: A Fun, Quirky Adventure The Good ‚Ä¢ Humor: The movie's humor is on point, with plenty of laugh-out-loud moments, especially when Jack Black and Jason Momoa are on screen together. Their chemistry is undeniable, making their scenes a joy to watch. ‚Ä¢ Visuals: The film's visuals are stunning, bringing the block-based world of Minecraft to life in a way that's both faithful to the source material and visually impressive. ‚Ä¢ Creativity: The movie celebrates creativity and self-expression, showcasing the importance of imagination and individuality. The Not-So-Good ‚Ä¢ Pacing: The pacing can be uneven at times, with some scenes feeling a bit disjointed from the rest of the story. ‚Ä¢ Plot Holes: Some plot points feel forced or underdeveloped, which can take away from the overall viewing experience. ‚Ä¢ Tone: The movie's tone can be inconsistent, veering wildly from slapstick comedy to action-adventure. Rating: 6.3/10

A Blockbuster Family Hit ‚Äì Literally! 4 out of 5 stars I went in with low expectations and came out with pixelated joy. As a family who‚Äôs spent more hours in Minecraft than we‚Äôd care to admit (yes, even me ‚Äì don‚Äôt judge), this movie hit the sweet spot: fun for the kids, surprisingly entertaining for the adults, and packed with just enough Minecraft spirit without feeling like a stretched-out YouTube tutorial. Jack Black is an absolute gem ‚Äì chaotic in the best way ‚Äì and Jason Momoa proves he can swing a pickaxe just as well as a trident. The rest of the cast? Surprisingly great chemistry, and they clearly had fun with it ‚Äì which makes it all the more enjoyable to watch. This isn't a direct retelling of Minecraft gameplay (thankfully, no 3-hour tree punching montage), but rather a creative tribute to the world-building, adventure, and weirdness we all love about the game. Bottom line: the kids were glued to the screen, we laughed more than expected, and we all left the theater with that warm, blocky feeling. Would mine it again.

While A Minecraft Movie certainly has its faults, its target audience is going to eat it up. All of the children in my screening were having a blast, as are Black and Momoa in this movie. This movie was not made for me, and that is perfectly fine. But I can appreciate and understand that the people it was made for are going to love it.

I walked into The Minecraft Movie expecting a fun, goofy little adventure. Something harmless and cute, maybe something that would make me smile once or twice and then fade from my memory like most video game adaptations tend to do. What I got instead was something wildly different‚Äîsomething that left me emotionally moved, artistically inspired, and genuinely changed. I‚Äôm not being dramatic when I say this movie shifted something inside me. It reminded me of what it means to create, to imagine, to heal. I didn‚Äôt just watch the movie‚ÄîI felt it. First of all, let‚Äôs talk about the surprise that is the actual plot. I didn‚Äôt expect anything too deep, considering the source material, but the story manages to be both silly and sincere. Two siblings‚ÄîHenry and Natalie‚Äîaccidentally get sucked into the Minecraft world during a glitch while trying to escape their messy, grief-stricken real lives. There, they meet Garrett Garrison, played by Jason Momoa, a washed-up retro gaming legend who‚Äôs been hiding from his past. And of course, there‚Äôs Steve. Yes, that Steve. Voiced by Jack Black with his signature explosive energy and unexpected tenderness, Steve somehow became my favorite character in the entire thing. I don‚Äôt even like Steve in the game. He‚Äôs just a skin. But here? He‚Äôs a full-blown icon. Watching this mismatched team try to navigate biomes, mobs, and emotional baggage somehow works. It‚Äôs chaotic in the best way. There‚Äôs a running joke about crafting tables that never gets old, and a jaw-dropping mid-movie sequence where they have to outrun a horde of skeletons across a collapsing stronghold bridge made entirely of redstone-powered pistons. Visually, the whole film is stunning. The animation doesn‚Äôt just mimic Minecraft‚Äîit elevates it. There‚Äôs something surprisingly beautiful about seeing a cube-shaped world rendered with so much love and attention to detail. Every block has texture. Every lighting choice feels intentional. Watching a pixelated sunrise over an in-game savanna biome actually made me gasp. Like‚Ä¶ why was that so emotional? But here‚Äôs where it gets personal. There‚Äôs a scene‚Äîsomewhere in the second act‚Äîwhere the characters are camped out near a lava flow in the Nether, and they‚Äôre talking about how, in Minecraft, when everything breaks, you can just start over. You can rebuild. Respawn. Try again. I didn‚Äôt think much of it at the time. It was a quiet little moment tucked between louder scenes. But something about that idea stuck with me. After the movie, I kept thinking about it. About how life doesn‚Äôt always give you clean respawns, but how the spirit of starting over‚Äîthat idea of taking what you‚Äôve got, even if it‚Äôs nothing but dirt and wood, and building a life‚Äîis so powerful. I went home and opened Minecraft for the first time in, what, four years? My old world was still there. My messy, half-finished castle. My abandoned railway system. I looked at it with fresh eyes. Not as something I‚Äôd failed to complete, but something I could continue. I started mining again. Not for anything in particular‚Äîjust for the joy of it. Just because I could. That‚Äôs what this movie did to me. It made me want to create again. And I haven‚Äôt even talked enough about the humor. The comedy in this movie is weird and delightful. There‚Äôs a zombie pigman band. There‚Äôs a group of villagers that worship a giant carrot statue. At one point, Garrett accidentally crafts 300 wooden hoes instead of a sword, and he just commits to using them in battle like twin nunchucks. And somehow, the movie makes fun of itself without ever becoming mean. It knows Minecraft is ridiculous. That‚Äôs what makes it special. And the movie never tries to make it something it‚Äôs not. It embraces the absurdity while anchoring it in real, heartfelt emotion. There are also some unexpected moments of brilliance from the supporting cast. Jennifer Coolidge plays a high-strung vice principal who gets stuck in a cave with a bunch of silverfish and decides to go full survival mode. She builds a mushroom-based empire and becomes a kind of in-game guru. I cannot explain how or why this works. It just does. Her line delivery? Impeccable. Her plot arc? Weirdly empowering. But at the core of the movie is a beating heart that I didn‚Äôt anticipate. A story about people‚Äîreal and pixelated‚Äîlearning how to connect, how to forgive, how to keep moving even when things fall apart. Minecraft, in its purest form, is about building something out of nothing. It‚Äôs about digging down deep, finding what‚Äôs buried, and making it your own. That metaphor lands hard in this movie. Maybe harder than I was ready for. I left the theater smiling like an idiot. Not because it was perfect‚Äîit wasn‚Äôt. Some jokes went on a little too long. Some character arcs could‚Äôve used more development. But it didn‚Äôt matter. I loved it. Fully. Unironically. Because it made me feel something real. Joy. Nostalgia. Creativity. Hope. So yeah. Five stars. No hesitation. This movie reminded me what it felt like to be a kid again, discovering Minecraft for the first time. It reminded me how powerful a little blocky world can be. How much heart can exist inside a grid of squares. And most of all, it reminded me that even in the messiest, most uncertain parts of life, we can still build something beautiful. Even if it‚Äôs just out of dirt.

If your not familiar with the source material or haven't seen a video game movie ever before than this should'nt be the first you ever see. But if you have it is an entertaining time. It's never boring, filled with life, stupidity, and action. It really doesn't have anything clever, thought provoking, or any deep character development though. It makes sense and the things in the world are consistent. It does assume you've played the game and only explains the bare minimum which to Black's credit he does a great job at. He never sounds like a souless NPC just explaining plot he does it with an understanding of what he's saying and sounds like a actual person. Everyone else isn't bad. Momoa would be second in this and the kids are alright enough but probably the weakest things. Coolidge and her sidegag plot is so pointless and could've been cut completely. The special effects and set design are pretty good actually and there is a lot of practical set design which was suprising and makes it so they can do more with the camerawork. I appreciated that. Yes there will be tons of moments that go over your head here but it makes sense on a barebone story level. If your a fan of any actors in this or the game give this a shot. But if not,, see some other video game movies or play the game first before. Defintely can see this being a Millenial/Gen Z "Rocky Horror Picture Show" type of flick for years to come.

Well...there is a reason why this film isn't called THE Minecraft Movie. It's not meant to be a definitive statement on an iconic video game, it's just meant to be a silly family-friendly romp that revolves around the Minecraft IP. A promotion from "A" to "The" is likely to be done in a potential sequel, and this film's success clearly indicates that such a thing is in the cards for Warner Bros. There's not a lot of meaningful character development and the emotional scenes tend to fall flat when you remember that this film is set over the course of barely a single day, and isn't operating under 24-style tension with only two characters having a meaningful connection to each other. It's basically an inferior version of the Jumanji reboot-quels without the gimmick of those films. Nevertheless, there's still fun to be had in A Minecraft Movie with well-rendered CGI, Jack Black and Jason Momoa hamming it up (though the latter does end up at times feeling like a rehash of Uncle Rico from Napoleon Dynamite), a couple of amusing gags, a fun "Mad Max: Fury Road"-style chase scene and a feeling that the filmmakers were trying to be respectful to Minecraft fans. There's a reason why the Technoblade tribute is considered a signature scene, at least one unrelated to the memes, anyway. Shame it comes off as random for people locked out of the loop. At least put an "In Memoriam" in the end credits for some context. Also, this Minecraft film sure likes to murder characters onscreen, doesn't it? Never thought the guy who directed the funny Jack Black luchador movie had it in him to go about "unaliving" some of the flora and fauna of Minecraft. It's almost as if it's based off of a survival game or something. A clich√©d but still reasonably popcorn-friendly video game movie which isn't on the same level as the Super Mario Bros. or Sonic movies, but isn't trying to be like them either. It can certainly take pride in being called "The Rocky Horror Picture Show of video game movies"...that quote had better be on the back of the DVD & Blu-ray cases.

The movie is honest from the very beginning sequence of the film as to what tone is intended with it and what it wants to communicate. And it does a good job maintaining that tone and message throughout the movie. As long as you understand what it is you're watching, you know this isn't a flick that takes itself serious, it's meant to be fun, it's meant to provide nostalgia for Minecraft fans, it offers a slight message encouraging creativity, but it doesn't shove it down your throat, I saw no political undertones to press anybody's buttons, it's just meant to be a bucket of buttery popcorn fun and easy amusement with the spouse and kids, something people of every walk of life can connect over, which is needed. The character development isn't very in-depth and it isn't meant to be, however, Danielle Brooks as Dawn provided a very motherly presence, especially to Emma's character, Natalie. Emma is an okay actress, she mostly looks surprised every time I see her on screen, but she did a decent job portraying a sister with a very tragic and important task of looking after her younger brother as an unfortunately placed parental figure. And I did find myself caring about the character. Sebastian as Henry, played a kid who coped with his loss with creativity, which he found in this new world that opened up to him. Of course, Jack Black is Jack Black. Nothing much more to say about his performance. Jason Mamoa, he did a decent job playing a down on his luck quasi-celebrity, known for video game exploits and trying to survive off of a dying business. Nothing deep to be said about his character, I mean... I guess his story arch was that he needed a friend? *Shrug* There were no seat-gripping climactic moments. There were no real stakes other than Natalie's protective duty over Henry, and I wasn't exactly biting my nails on that one either. It was just a silly romp in video game nostalgia, in a colorful and quirky kind of CGI world, with a cast of outcasts you didn't mind spending time with. It also had some very faint Napoleon Dynamite vibes, in my honest opinion, which, isn't a good or bad thing. Four stars seems reasonable.

What do I have to say about 'A Minecraft Movie'? There are 3 kinds of people that book tickets to see this film: 1. You're intrigued by the fact theaters are covered in pocorn after the (in)famous Chicken Jockey, 2. You're nostalgic for the original game and decide to give the movie a go, 3. You're a big nerd and are there to freak out over all the references. And honestly, I fit in in all three categories. I grew up with both playing the Minecraft game and watching YouTube series about/set in the game, but as a movie nerd I'm also intrigued by the cultural phenonimal the movie turned into. It was bound to happen. I was legit nervous to what audience I would meet in the theater. Turns out it were just some 18-year olds and parents with their kids. There were maybe 4 people reacting to Chicken Jockey, including myself. On the other hand, that gave me the opportunity to make up a legit judgement of this movie. And it is a lot of fun! Don't expect the plot to be anything great, it's still aimed at kids after all. But they manage to explore the Overworld and everything that makes it so iconic, though they also take their creative liberties which only enhances the movie. Jack Black as Steve is just so fun, like what you expect him to be based on the trailers and his previous roles, that's what you'll get. For me the personal standout was Danielle Brooks, who was so hilarious in this movie, and I really hope this movie will launch off a promising career for Sebastian Eugene Hansen. Emma Myers also did good, Jason Momoa also caused for some laughs, but also could take this movie to its hysterical heights. The Piglins made for surprisingly good villains, especially with the inevitable sequel rumoured to be already in the making in sight, which would make for a better stage for the Ender Dragon as the main villain. What truely blew me away was the CGI. At very little moments you 'saw' the green screen, the CGI of the Overworld was very convincing 99% of the time. Overall it's just a fun simple movie to tune out for some time, with the love for the game and the fandom being evident to those who have as big of a love for the game as the people who 'crafted' this movie!

A surprising box office hit that very few saw coming‚Äîdoes Minecraft live up to‚Ä¶ well, anything? My opinion (that you didn‚Äôt ask for): We all need a bit of absolutely chaotic fun every now and then, and this movie delivered it in a way that (very pleasantly) surprised me. If you have kids who love the game‚Äîor if you‚Äôre a fan yourself‚Äîyou‚Äôll probably have a great time (there was a whole group of people dressed as Steve when my nephews went to see it). It‚Äôs definitely a screen. If you have no idea what the game is but need a break from checking the balance of your 401(k), I recommend streaming it. Before I go any further... Spoiler warning: This review contains spoilers. If you're spoiler-averse, check out the two-minute spoiler-free version on my TikTok (@uninvited.reviewe) or Instagram (@uninvited_reviewer). I wasn‚Äôt expecting much from this movie. But I‚Äôm thrilled to say I got more than I ever anticipated. Turns out, when you throw Jack Black, Jason Momoa, Jennifer Coolidge, Danielle Brooks (a quickly rising star recently seen in Wednesday, A Good Girl‚Äôs Guide to Murder, and set to appear in The Angry Birds Movie 3), and newcomer Sebastian Hansen into a project based on a video game with no real storyline... you get a little bit of genius, a whole lot of ridiculousness, and some genuinely laugh-out-loud moments. Surprised? Yeah, me too. That doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs a good movie, per se. Does it have substance? No. Style? Not really. But does it care? Absolutely not. And that level of self-awareness‚Äîknowing exactly what it is (a blatant money grab)‚Äîactually works in its favor. Because rather than being weighed down by the high expectations (and bloated budgets) of other video-game-to-movie flops‚Äî cough Tomb Raider (2018) Warcraft Assassin‚Äôs Creed Mortal Kombat (Feel free to hit me up with any I‚Äôm missing) cough‚Äî ‚Äîit just chooses to be fun. Or, in the wise words of my nephew: ‚ÄúIt was stupid, but funny, so I didn‚Äôt care.‚Äù Take the opening, for example. The movie kicks off with a seven-minute monologue by Jack Black‚Äîsomething that would usually bore me to tears (movie plots should be seen, not told, thank you very much). But I was completely drawn in by Jack Black‚Äôs total Jack Black-ness. Not many actors can base an entire character on their own personality and get away with it. But not every actor is Jack Black, and he was totally let off the leash for this one. Next, we meet Jason Momoa‚Äôs character, Garrett "The Garbage Man" Garrison‚Äîa (very) former video game champion who refuses to give up on his childhood dreams. His refusal to grow up is endearing in a wild, chaotic kind of way. His chemistry with Jack Black is what really anchors the movie. They flirt with going way over the top more times than I can count, but somehow always manage to reel it back in just enough. Danielle Brooks and Sebastian Hansen play Natalie and Henry, two siblings who move to Chuglass, Idaho‚Äîa town whose mascot is a potato named Chuggy (memorably and quickly destroyed by Henry in one of the funnier early moments). They‚Äôre joined by Dawn, their eccentric real estate agent-slash-mobile-zoo-owner, rounding out the core cast. At just 101 minutes, this movie doesn‚Äôt spend time on much of anything other than providing a sandbox for Black and Momoa to play around in. The plot jumps all over the place with no real rhyme or reason‚Äîbut if you walked into Minecraft expecting coherent structure or emotional depth, you might have missed the memo. Final Thoughts: This movie lacks deeper meaning, substance, or a traditional narrative arc. But it‚Äôs fun. It‚Äôs funny. And it‚Äôs ludicrous enough to keep both kids and adults entertained. Think of it as cinematic junk food: no nutrition, but man, it hits the spot. unwantedmoviereviews.com

I'm still reeling from the cinematic experience that is the Minecraft movie. As a die-hard fan of the game, I was both excited and apprehensive about how the filmmakers would translate the beloved franchise to the big screen. But let me tell you, they absolutely nailed it! From the opening scene, I was transported to the blocky, pixelated world I know and love, Jack Black being the perfect transport. The visuals were stunning, perfectly capturing the game's unique aesthetic. The characters, environments, and creatures all looked exactly as I imagined them. The attention to detail was impressive, from the textures to the animations. The story was engaging, action-packed, and full of surprises. The filmmakers cleverly wove together elements from various game modes, creating a narrative that felt both authentic and fresh. The characters' motivations and relationships were well-developed, making it easy to become invested in their journey. The casting was spot-on, with each actor bringing their respective character to life with enthusiasm and charm. The dialogue was witty, humorous, and often nostalgic for fans of the game. I found myself laughing out loud at several moments, and the references to Minecraft lore had me grinning from ear to ear. The action scenes were intense, thrilling, and visually stunning. The special effects were seamless, making it impossible to distinguish between what's CGI and what's real. The pacing was well-balanced, with a perfect blend of quiet moments and explosive set pieces. What truly impressed me, however, was the film's faithfulness to the game's spirit. The movie captured the essence of Minecraft's creativity, exploration, and survival mechanics, making it a love letter to fans of the game. The filmmakers clearly understood what makes Minecraft special and incorporated those elements seamlessly into the story. If I have any criticisms, it's that the movie sometimes felt a bit rushed. Some plot points could have been fleshed out more, and certain characters felt slightly underdeveloped. However, these minor quibbles didn't detract from my overall enjoyment. The Minecraft movie is a must-see for fans of the game and newcomers alike. It's an adventure-filled, visually stunning, and heartwarming film that will leave you feeling uplifted and eager for more. The filmmakers have set the bar high for franchise movies, and I'm already counting down the days until the sequel. In short, the Minecraft movie is a masterpiece. It's a testament to the power of creativity, imagination, and the enduring appeal of the Minecraft universe. If you're a fan of action, adventure, fantasy, or Minecraft itself, do yourself a favor and get tickets ASAP. Trust me, you won't regret it! Rating: 5/5 stars Recommendation: Don't miss this movie if you enjoy: - Action-adventure films - Fantasy worlds - Video game adaptations - Family-friendly content - Nostalgic references Post-credits scene: Yes, there is one, and it's worth sticking around for!

Honestly, A Minecraft Movie really surprised me in a good way. I walked into the theater thinking it would just be for kids, but I walked out feeling like I had just been part of a great adventure. I loved how the movie shows the importance of building, protecting, and creating your own space ‚Äî kind of like putting up a fence in real life to take care of what matters most. The animation is beautiful, especially the scenes with the pandas, which are pure joy. Jason Momoa and Jack Black bring a ton of energy and humor, and even though some parts feel a little rushed, overall the movie keeps a fun and engaging pace. Its a love letter to anyone who ever got lost for hours building in Minecraft. You dont have to be a huge fan to enjoy it, but if youve ever loved the idea of creating and defending your own world, this movie will hit you right in the heart.
